cards.back: A_V = -g_m × R_C. Negative = phase inversion. g_m = I_C/V_T.
R_in = r_π || R₁ || R₂, where r_π = β/g_m.
R_out ≈ R_C (neglecting r_o). With Early effect: R_out = R_C || r_o.
Shorts R_E for AC signals → restores full gain -g_m·R_C. Without it, gain = -R_C/(r_e+R_E).

cards.front: Why does CE invert the signal?
cards.back: ↑V_in → ↑I_C → ↑V_RC → ↓V_CE. More current through R_C drops more voltage, reducing V_CE.
A_I ≈ β. The CE configuration provides full current amplification.
Unbypassed R_E: A_V = -R_C/(r_e + R_E). Lower gain but better linearity and thermal stability via negative feedback.

cards.front: CE power gain compared to CB and CC?
cards.back: CE has the HIGHEST power gain (A_P = |A_V| × A_I). CB has lower current gain. CC has lower voltage gain.
